title: Thursday, 10th March, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Morning

PM

Welcome

PM

Rabobank asks:

11:01 am
PM

Manic Thursday?

PM

hmm

PM

I'm feeling quite stable, relatively

11:01 am
PM

They are talking about the ECB of course

PM

which we can maybe come back to

PM

Things v v quiet ahead of Draghi

11:02 am
BE

Indeed. The mania is at a level that's barely perceptible.

PM

But are things this quiet...

PM

One could almost hear the silence on European trading floors yesterday, as the Governing Council started their meeting in Frankfurt behind closed doors and market participants were taking their final positions. Those doors will only open this afternoon for the regular press conference hosted by the ECB President. Will Mr. Draghi be able to inject fresh confidence after the market’s negative response to the ‘comprehensive’ easing package in December last year?

11:02 am
BE

Where's that from?

PM

( L -- you after a job or something?

PM

Rabobank Bryce

11:03 am
BE

"One could almost hear the silence on European trading floors yesterday" is an interesting sentence. Almost Zen.

PM

Anyway

PM

We should have a pic of John Gutfreund i guess

11:04 am
PM

PM

There

PM

You're welcome

11:05 am
undefined
PM

Another image to share...

PM

11:06 am
PM

That's Sweetings, from Bloomberg

PM

Who have discovered the fish and chip place next door to their new London headquarters

PM

http://www.bloombe...nkers-and-gangters

PM

PM

But it doesnt matter

PM

Ive decided that Sweetings is just too expensive

11:07 am
PM

£20.75 dressed crab,

PM

Compared with £16 for brilliant dressed crab in Wright Brothers

BE

Yeah, it's absurd. But it only does a lunch service so I guess it needs to charge double.

11:07 am
PM

Sweets dover sole is £38 in Sweetings

PM

£36 in Sheekey's

PM

Only so often you'd pay so much for (albeit brilliant) atmosphere

11:09 am
PM

One other thing to note from this Bloomberg piece...

PM

Richard Vines is chief food critic for Bloomberg

BE

He is, yes.

11:09 am
PM

How may food critics do they have?

BE

..... I guess they have one for every big financial city. I'm fairly sure Richard's the only one in London.

BE

And he's been there for several decades, which tends to require title elevation.

11:10 am
PM

Yeah, i guess he might be poached

PM

omg smile

BE

Incidentally, £38 isn't that bad for a Dover sole. Wholesale you're looking at £8-ish, and the actual food cost's about 30% on average.

11:12 am
PM

Yeah, but the presentation at Sheekey's is rather better..

BE

For a crab, though, £20+ is properly hilarious.

PM

Anyway, isnt this the point at which you suggest that we move to the financial section of the show?

11:12 am
BE

Usually, yes. But as we've already said, we're somewhat lacking in mania.

PM

(Pharma -- I didn mean it! embarassed smile )

BE

I'm perfectly happy to talk about the wholesale price of dressed crabs for an hour.

11:13 am
BE

(@St Andrean: one difference there is that the glass box in St Andrews is entirely rubbish.)

undefined
BE

Fourteen minutes of preamble. That was good going.

11:14 am
PM

I can do more if you like

PM

No, ok

BE

Let's not. There are a couple of things happening.

11:15 am
BE

FTSE down and Ashtead leading us there.

Ashtead Group PLC (AHT:LSE): Last: 804.50, down 48 (-5.63%), High: 838.00, Low: 790.00, Volume: 1.46m
BE

Quite a sentiment shift in Ashtead post results.

11:16 am
BE

Credit Suisse downgrade yesterday, I think,while Deutsche today is extremely negative.

PM

( roddy1234 -- yes, it will crumble soon enough)

PM

What are Deutsche saying?

11:17 am
BE

Well, it's largely on the heavily veiled profit warning from ......... last week, was it?

BE

The one where you needed to know that capex was a proxy for fleet growth, which was a proxy for earnings growth.

BE

Deutsche says, "why's this highly cyclical cyclical still at nearly 14 times earnings?"

11:18 am
BE

Ashtead is the no.2 equipment rental player in both North America and the UK.
It operates under the brands "Sunbelt" in North America (84% of FY15A sales)
and "A-Plant" in the UK (16% of FY15A sales).

PM

(TheLeggie: -- actually I spent a week as a food critic many years ago. Reviewed the City Circle. Had some fun with it. They wrote a six page letter of complaint -- and closed down three weeks later. Think it's a hawksmoor now.)

BE

(That was the place where Catherine Zeta Jones waited tables, right? That's a good war story.)

11:19 am
BE

Ashtead is a highly cyclical stock. Key to our bear case is that its 12m forward
PE has historically de-rated long before EPS downgrades or a visible slowdown
in the US non-residential construction (its largest end market). As such, we
anticipate the de-rating of the PE to continue. It is currently trading on 9.5x
consensus 12m fwd PE (vs 13.6x long term median and 2.4x prior trough). We
think investors interested in the compelling longer term structural growth story
that Ashtead has to offer should wait for a more interesting entry point.

PM

(roddy1234 -- it stretches from Sweetings to Cannon Street station. You can't miss it. Literally.)

BE

As a team we have bearish on the US for some time, and we do not consider
the non-residential market immune from our concerns. Furthermore, analysis
shows that the top 10 oil states contributed to an average of 48% of
incremental construction spend (ex. power, communication and railroad) in
2012-14, driving further concerns over the US construction end markets.

11:19 am
BE

Ashtead is operationally geared, with a 63% EBITDA same-stores drop through
rate in its US business Sunbelt. We believe that this level of operational
gearing may well cause market concern in a worsening macro environment.

BE

We consider Ashtead to have reached peak returns on capital. We expect
competition in US equipment rental to intensify, as small to mid-sized players
gain increased access to cheap bank lending. As such, we anticipate Ashtead’s
returns on capital to reduce over the coming years due to increased
competition in the industry.

BE

We think the market places greater emphasis on multiples than on DCF
valuations at points of earnings turnaround. We place a 7x PE on peak EPS
forecasts (FY18E) to reach our TP of 660p. Upside risks include FX risk
(USD/GBP), stronger macro environment, lower operational gearing than
forecasted and weaker than expected pricing pressure in the US market.

11:20 am
undefined
BE

Aviva mentioned. Decent rebound.

PM

Yeah, finals today

11:21 am
PM

http://www.investe...1603100700086190R/

PM

It's a confident statement from Mark Watson

PM

Mark WIlson as well

11:21 am
BE

The rebound is not unlike the Pru rebound yesterday, which was apropos of a Pru paying a dividend it can ill afford.

BE

Aviva looks a bit stronger though. Profit and capital both beat consensus.

Aviva PLC (AV.:LSE): Last: 477.80, up 18.2 (+3.96%), High: 485.20, Low: 469.90, Volume: 10.84m
11:23 am
BE

Higher shareholder returns are flagged up -- which some might see as a bit high risk given the constant uncertainties of Solvency legislation but I guess it's positive when everyone else is cutting.

BE

Here's Barclays with the one-par summary.

BE

Aviva reported FY15 earnings ahead of consensus on all metrics, gave additional colour on the capital synergies from the Friends deal (£1.2bn) and reported a better-than-expected Solvency 2 number (180%, at the top of its range and above our 166% estimate). Total operating profit of £2.7bn was 7% ahead of consensus. Aviva Investors at £106m was the largest earnings beat, 29% ahead of consensus, but Life Insurance (4% ahead at £2.4bn) and General Insurance (5% ahead at £765m) were also better than expected. The company announced a dividend increase of 15% YoY to 20.8p, in line with our estimate and the H1 2015 increase, although this was slightly below consensus (2/3 analysts expected +15% and 1/3 +20%). However, the main news was on Solvency 2 and benefits of the Friends deal. Solvency 2 ratio at FY15 was 180%, above our estimate of 166% and at the top end of the company’s working range of 150% to 180%. The ratio only fell by 6pts at the low point of the February 2016 markets (vs 20 points at Allianz, 15 points at AXA, 13 points at Prudential). Aviva expects to achieve the £225m of expense synergies from Friends Life deal 12 months early by the end of 2016. There will be more expense synergies, but the company will not disclose them as the companies are now fully integrated. The company expects to achieve £1.2bn of capital synergies from the Friends deal of which £400m of diversification benefit is already achieved. As a result Aviva expects its UK life company to remit £1bn of cash over and above its normal run-rate over the next three years. The CFO suggested that if Aviva does not need the money to reinvest, the company will consider additional distributions to shareholders.

11:24 am
BE

And Morgan Stanley.

BE

Reassuring Solvency 2 capital ratio - higher than we anticipated,
resilient under stress. Aviva's Solvency 2 ratio of 180% at FY15 is a solid
ratio - and at the upper end of the newly established capital policy range of
150-180%. Furthermore, the ratio is relatively insensitive to shocks - for e.g.
25% fall in equity markets would result in 177% (vs 180% base), 25bps decline
in interest rates (176%) and 100 bps spread widening on corporate bonds
(177%). A repeat of the 2008 financial crisis would reduce the ratio to 141%.

BE

Solvency 2 capital generation of £2.7 billion for FY15, prior to cental
items. We estimate that excluding these items Solvency 2 capital generation
was ~£1.8 billion - or 14-15 points on the Solvency 2 ratio. This suggests
capital build of ~7 points per annum. While there are some one-offs in 2015,
we note the ongoing guidance that the solvency ratio post dividend will grow
at 5-10 points per annum.
IFRS operating profit beat by 7%, operating EPS ahead of expectations
by 13%. Operating profit beat expectations across all segments, although the
absolute largest contribution came from the life operations (driving £85m out
of total beat of £176m). Aviva Investors beat by 29% and contributed ~4% of
group operating profit. EPS was further ahead due to a lower tax rate.

11:25 am
BE

Friends Life cost synergies of £225m likely to be achieved a year early
(2016 rather than 2017) and capital benefits quantified at £1.2 billion
(of which £0.4 billion have already been delivered). The capital synergies
allow management to commit to bring back to group an additional £1 billion
of cash over the next 3 years (over and above the normal course of business).
General insurance combined ratio of 94.6% vs 96.0% expected and
95.7% in the prior year. This includes absorbing the £132m cost of the
December floods. However, the underlying claims ratio deteriorated to 67.8%
(FY14: 65.4%), in aggregate weather was 0.1% below long-run average and
reserve releases were 3.2 points (FY14: 1.6 points).
Overall a solid set of numbers - with robust solvency and balance sheet
the highlight - we re-iterate our Overweight recommendation. Aviva is
trading at 8.4x FY17e (9.0x consensus) and yielding 4.6% on the just declared
dividend for FY15.

BE

Morgan Stanley's shop broker, I think.

BE

(@St Andrean: no matter how much I read, I find Pru capital ratios entirely baffling.)

11:26 am
undefined
BE

Speaking of divi cuts ........

WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 196.80, down 5.2 (-2.57%), High: 203.30, Low: 194.50, Volume: 5.01m
11:27 am
PM

Yeah, i was reading through the statement and thought it was rather positive

PM

The divi cut was priced in, surely

PM

Well

11:27 am
PM

Obviously not

PM

It's a deep detail, well written statement. Full of sensible things.

PM

And the market reaction: "theyve cut the divid -2/3%

11:28 am
BE

Remember Morrisons' recent rally that pushed it back into the FTSE. There's not much in the results that's surprising but there's a travel-arrive argument to play here.

PM

Ok, yeah

PM

I get that

11:28 am
BE

A reminder, for instance, that the Amazon deal was seen as a positive.

BE

Morrison supplying goods wholesale to the world's biggest retailer to sell at below cost in direct competition to its own service, which it agreed on a multi-decade licence deal on spectacularly onerous terms.

BE

A positive.

11:30 am
BE

So anyway, Q4 LFL is 0.1% against a consensus of 0.0%.

BE

(As in, a rounding error.)

BE

Underlying PBT is £302m, in the middle of January guidance of £295-310m.

11:31 am
BE

Net debt also in the middle of guidance, £1.75bn, and there's nothing whatsoever on the strategic side.

BE

Now, I guess what to note here is that Morrison's on 16 times 2017.

BE

A premium to sector.

11:32 am
BE

Operational gearing is the reason for that, of course. A historic view of Morrison's PE ratios make it look like a dot-comedy stock at times.

PM

ha

BE

Still -- 16 times 2017 is quite a lot to pay for a work in progress.

11:33 am
BE

SocGen incoming.

PM

yeah, ok

PM

I get the picture

11:33 am
PM

But what are SocGen saying?

BE

Main surprises Underlying PBT excl. restructuring and store closures stood at £302m,
slightly below our forecast (SGe: £309m; consensus: £306) and in the middle of the group’s
targeted range (£295-310m). Total dividend of 5p, is just consistent with the group’s target
(of not below 5p). Good control of cash, as expected, with year-end net debt of £1,746m
(targeted range of £1.65-1.8bn). Outlook. The group gave a rather cautious outlook, which
is consistent with the still-tough environment in the UK. Management stated that ‘the
turnaround will take time and will continue to require sustained investment in the
proposition’. In the medium term, management expects £50-100m incremental underlying
PBT. We expect +£41m in 2018-19e vs 2015-16. This means that rebuilding profitability will
take time and the scope to further improve margins is limited.

BE

Potential impact on SG & market forecast We do not expect any significant change in
consensus estimates.
Potential impact on share price/recommendation We maintain our Sell recommendation
as the stock is expensive and a blue-sky margin recovery scenario is already priced in,
which is not justified in the short term, in our view. A correction would be justified. Our TP
is based on a peer comparison (160p at a 15% discount to the European sector average
2016-17e EV/sales ratio) and a DCF (140p, 8.4% WACC, 1.5% growth to perpetuity, 3.4%
norm. EBIT margin as of 2022-23e). Risks to price target, rating & recommendation: If
Morrison demonstrates an unexpectedly strong ability to improve its market share trends (-
20bp in the 12 weeks to 6 December) and protect its LFL sales growth (all else being equal,
1% of additional LFL sales leads to a 20bp EBIT margin improvement); or if it can
successfully develop the e-commerce business (currently less than 2% of sales in FY15-16
on our estimates); and/or if there is any significant easing in price competition (SGe: £150m
of price investment by Morrisons in FY16-17e).

11:34 am
BE

And Stifel.

BE

Full year profits and cash generation are in line with expectations and the four weeks of previously unreported LfL growth suggest only a modest slowdown from the solid Christmas performance. Guidance on future cash generation is also in line and future dividend cover of c.2x matches consensus. Profit guidance is more interesting, with management citing £50m-£100m of medium-term UPBT opportunity from broader business
opportunities including online and wholesale but a cautious message on the core business, citing the need for
“required investment in the proposition”. We think this is consistent with consensus which implies very modest underlying progress this year. At 21x next year’s EPS, we think the shares fairly value the mix of core pressure and broader opportunities and retain a Hold recommendation.

BE

Results
UPBT £302m vs. our estimate of £305m and guidance of £295m-£310m (pre
exceptionals and restructuring costs).
Restructuring costs exactly in line with guidance at £60m. NBD costs (online
and convenience) also in line at £47m.
Q4 LfL +0.1%, suggesting that the final four weeks of the quarter were a touch
lower than the +0.2% reported for the first nine weeks. LfL transactions +1.6%
in Q4.
Net debt £1.75bn, in line with guidance of £1.65bn-£1.8bn and our estimate of
£1.73bn.
FY DPS 5.0p (final 3.5p), in line with guided minimum level.
Guidance
Will realise remainder of cost savings targets in FY17 but turnaround “will take
time and will continue to require sustained investment in the proposition”.
£50m-£100m incremental UPBT in the medium term from “broader business
opportunities” – online, manufacturing, third party services (e.g. Timpsons),
wholesale and lower interest costs.
DPS “around 2x” cover ongoing, suggesting, on our EPS number (7% below
consensus), little progress next year. Versus consensus EPS of 10.6p, this
would suggest DPS of 5.3p, a 2.6% yield.
FY 17 net debt £1.4bn-£1.5bn, in line with our £1.48bn estimate.
FCF at least £300m better than original £1.5bn target, with working capital
target increased to at least £800m from £600m, property disposal proceeds to
at least £1.1bn from £1bn.

11:00 am
PM

This is Markets Live

PM

Why are we getting Vancouver stocks coming thru RNS now?

PM

Vancouver graphite stocks at that??

11:36 am
PM

http://www.investe...1603101120176990R/

BE

There's lots of dual-listed Toronto mining junk down on Aim.

PM

But this is a dot V stock

11:38 am
PM

I could show you the chart, but you already know what it looks like

BE

Fair enough. I'm going to spend lunch reading about spherical graphite.

undefined
11:39 am
BE

Argos requested, apropos of the year-end trading update.

Home Retail Group PLC (HOME:LSE): Last: 180.90, up 0.9 (+0.50%), High: 181.60, Low: 178.60, Volume: 2.05m
PM

Rubbish numbers, but no one cares

11:39 am
PM

In light of the bids

BE

Only covers eight weeks, in the post Christmas lull, and Homebase messes up the headlines.

BE

CEO's not saying anything particularly notable on the bids except what you'd expect about weighing up a multitude of factors.

11:42 am
BE

And basically, what happened here is that Home got spoofed into accepting a lowball offer from Sainsbury then were rescued totally out of leftfield by Steinhoff. You'd not expect the CEO to say anything more than "we're considering everything".

BE

Here's Canaccord to tell you the figures are largely irrelevant, which they are.

BE

Full-year LFL declined by 2.6% (vs consensus of a 2.2% decline and CGe down 2.7%), with a gross margin decline of c 50bps (vs consensus of a 74bps decline and CGe of a 75bps decline). Q4 saw LFL sales decline 1.1%, accompanied by a 75bps increase in gross margin. Total sales were up 1.9%, with a 3% contribution from new space, principally from the addition of digital concessions and collection points. Excluding the cannibalisation impact of around 1% from these, underlying LFL sales were broadly flat.

In terms of product categories, furniture and general sports performed well, with jewellery and the important electricals category seeing sales decline. Internet penetration continues to rise, with growth of 13% in Q4 translating to 51% of sales vs 46% last year. Sales from mobile devices rose 15%, accounting for 28% of Argos sales vs 25% last year.

11:43 am
BE

This is very much from a rear-view mirror perspective, with Home Retail having confirmed that the division's sale to Australian Group, Wesfarmers, was duly completed on 27 February. For the record, full-year LFL rose strongly by 5.2% (vs consensus of a 5.3% rise and CGe up 5.5%), with a gross margin decline of 125bps (vs consensus of a 94bps decline and CGe of a 100bps decline). Q4 saw LFL sales grow 3.3%, accompanied by a 225bps decline in gross margin.

BE

There was a much stronger performance than expected on the cash generation front. Year end underlying cash is flat at £310m, compared with consensus of £209m (FactSet) and CGe of £195m. No further insight was given as to the reasons for this, but this should come as welcome news for both potential bidders. Including the proceeds from the Homebase disposal, year end cash will be £625m.

BE

Unless one of the two interested parties decides to withdraw from the bidding process for Home Retail, which appears unlikely at this stage, and assuming an increased offer from J Sainsbury, there is likely to be another extension to bid deadlines. Currently, Steinhoff's all-cash 175p per share offer is above J Sainsbury's mixed paper and cash offer. With the shares trading above the Steinhoff offer, the market is clearly discounting an increased bid (or bids).

Consensus forecast for FY16 Group Benchmark PBT stands at £93m, as does CGe's forecast, with the company confirming today that the FY16 outturn will be in line with consensus. Consensus forecasts for operating profit at the two key divisions stand at £79m for Argos and £28m at Homebase, with CGe on £75m and £31m.

At last night's close - and based on profit forecasts inclusive of the now sold Homebase division - Home Retail's shares are trading on a cal 16 PER of 19.3x falling to 17.7x for cal 17.

11:44 am
BE

Though since we're here ........... why did Argos open 90 new stores this year?

BE

I guess they were closing the ones in the wrong places. Still, though, the 1% cannibalisation referred to in the statement seems entirely avoidable.

undefined
11:46 am
PM

Suppose we should say something about Draghi

PM

David shared a very good ready reckoner earlier

PM

http://ftalphavill...a-draghi-day-menu/

11:46 am
PM

So have a read of that

PM

But i note some comments have also just dropped from William Porter

PM

of Credit Suisse

11:47 am
PM

Who is always worth a read for a slightly different view

PM

Please disappoint us, Mr. Draghi

PM

We do not think the ECB is driving the recovery in risk appetite; the recovery is
too globally synchronized for that. We are buyers on dips. It follows that we hope
that the ECB can provide one by disappointing: we are not really looking to it for
ultimate direction in our market. The danger is the opposite of disappointment,
that the ECB exceeds expectations that have reduced with index spreads. So
we might well see a sharp move after the meeting and the danger is it is tighter.
But in either direction we would tend to fade a sharp reaction

11:47 am
PM

150 or so S+P points work wonders; suddenly recession fears are less
prevalent and the considerable stress we felt in holding on to the nonrecession
view during February eases substantially. So it is time to be a bit
more cautious. Just to state one obvious corollary, some of the pressure is off
the ECB. Or, a bit more specifically, the ability of the ECB GC to do almost
literally anything it wants, as we examined last time, is subject to the activists
achieving a 2/3 vote. And that is complicated by the better market tone.

PM

Of course some of that better tone is itself due to ECB expectations–hence our
point that the nature of the situation is to remove some volatility–but we stick
with our view that the global cycle is actually more important. Look at the
below correlation between the HY markets; is US HY better because of the
ECB? We think not.

PM

So Porter's worry is that Draghi does too much

11:48 am
BE

(@Whoever was asking about the new Bloomberg HQ, SkyscraperCity has loads of pictures and considerably discussion on its architectural merits: http://www.skyscra...f&t=351887&page=72 )

PM

Actually, this is quite a detailed note from Porter

PM

I will usual place it

11:49 am
PM

And here's some Greg Fuzesi

PM

JPM

PM

New staff forecasts to justify a big package
We expect the new staff forecast to put pressure on Draghi to deliver (see more details here). Growth will be revised lower again, with downside risk. January activity data have been strong, easing concerns about 1Q16, but the global backdrop remains difficult. On inflation, 2016 will be cut sharply from 1.0%oya to just 0.2%oya due to lower oil prices, while 2018 will be projected at 1.8%oya largely because the staff will assume a fully closed output gap by then. But, 2017 could be cut significantly due to the stronger currency and lagged effects from lower oil prices. In our own modelling, we do not find such lagged effects from oil price falls, but the Bundesbank has argued that it could shave 0.3%-pts off the German forecast, even if there are no second-round effects via wages. Based on this, we expect core inflation to be cut to 1.4%oya in 2017, which has been Draghi’s focus until now and which would be 0.3%-pts below the forecast made last March. Since the cut-off date for these forecasts, oil prices have bounced and the currency has eased back. This would not change the forecasts much. Higher oil prices raise the near-term profile but the forward curve is flatter, which could lower headline inflation in 2018 to 1.7%oya.

11:50 am
PM

What goes into the package?
Hawkish governors will undoubtedly point to the 2018 inflation forecast, but Draghi has elevated the projection for 2017 to a test of the ECB’s credibility. He can also emphasise that it remains subject to downside risk. On this basis, we think that it would be reasonable for the ECB to deliver a package of at least 4% of GDP, in QE-equivalent terms, which would aim at lifting inflation by at least 0.2%-pts (according to Draghi’s rule of thumb). This can be delivered in many ways. What is easiest for the Governing Council to agree to is a 10bp deposit rate cut without tiering and a six-month QE extension. This is too back-loaded however and delivers less than what is required.

PM

Hence, some difficult decisions will need to be taken. Our expectation remains a package that includes a 20bp deposit rate cut, a tiered deposit rate system (or a very strong signal that it is coming), a €10bn increase in the QE purchase pace, a three-month extension of QE until mid-2017, additional TLTROs during 2H16 with easier conditions (negative rates, 4-year maturities and easier lending multiples) and some QE modality changes (removal of deposit rate floor, larger maturity bucket and higher issue limits on non-CAC bonds). See here for more detail on the modality changes. Relative to what we expected for the December meeting, this package is somewhat bigger, mainly due to the larger deposit rate cut, the implementation (or signal) of a tiered system and the TLTROs. The latter makes sense to us as a way of “steering” QE to the real economy and should be easy to implement. The main challenge is that they would need to be offered at negative rates, which requires explanation, and that they must fit into any tiered reserve remuneration system, which is possible.

We doubt that QE will be extended to new asset classes or that the capital key will be dropped. In terms of risks, it is possible that the ECB will cut the deposit rate by only 10bp, especially if it adopts a tiered system and uses this to reinforce its forward guidance. Similarly, the ECB might opt for a longer QE extension whilst leaving the monthly pace unchanged. But, overall, we continue to think that our forecast is reasonable in terms of magnitude.

PM

That'll do

11:50 am
undefined
BE

(And thanks, @reader I won't identify, for the 3,000 word email regarding spherical graphite.)

PM

hehehe

11:52 am
BE

What else can we do? It's a struggle when it's this dull.

BE

Goldman's downgraded Rolls, which I guess is notable.

Rolls-Royce Holdings PLC (RR.:LSE): Last: 690.82, down 9.18 (-1.31%), High: 697.50, Low: 681.50, Volume: 2.07m
11:52 am
BE

Even if it's not particularly share-price sensitive.

BE

Valuation, mostly.

BE

We remove Rolls-Royce from the Pan-European Buy List and downgrade it
to Neutral. Since being added to the Buy List on September 29, 2015 (see
Rethinking Rolls-Royce), shares in Rolls-Royce are up 10% (vs. the FTSE
World Europe +4.5%) despite consensus (company-compiled) 2016 EBIT
forecasts falling 35%. Rolls-Royce significantly underperformed in 4Q2015
as a result of the November profit warning, but ytd the shares are up 23%,
vs. the Stoxx -8% and FTSE World Europe -2.3%. As a result of this rerating
in valuation multiples, we believe the current share price fully
reflects the medium-term opportunity set; hence our Neutral rating.

11:53 am
BE

Our 2016-18 EBIT estimates fall by 5%, 3% and 4%, driven by more
significant headwinds in the Large Engine aftermarket and higher costs in
the Marine division. Our 2016 EBIT forecast is 17% ahead of companycompiled
consensus, driven entirely by our view of Civil Aerospace EBIT
(detailed within this note).
Rolls-Royce currently trades at 9x 2017E EV/DACF (our preferred valuation
metric) vs. an average of 10x for our coverage; however, we forecast a
lower DACF CAGR (2015-18E) for RR vs. our coverage (8% vs. 11%).
Similarly, on a Director’s Cut (EV/GCI vs. CROCI/WACC) valuation
methodology, we believe Rolls-Royce now looks fairly priced.
Our revised 12-month price target of 725p (up from 711p) implies 3%
upside and is based on 10.1x 2017E EV/DACF, discounted back one year at
an 8% WACC. We have raised our target multiple from 9x as we remove a
10% execution discount following better-than-expected Trent XWB losses.
Risks to our view and price target include (1) FX moves, particularly in
USD/GBP; (2) better/worse-than-expected defence markets; (3)
better/worse-than-expected sanctioning in offshore O&G capex; and (4)
programme risks such as those relating to Trent XWB and Trent 1000.

BE

Cineworld had what we regard as a very strong year in 2015. EBITDA
was up 18.5% on a proforma basis to £155m, 1% above our estimate. A
record 18 new sites were opened across the estate. 2016 has started well,
especially in CEE and Israel, but the UK has also been solid and in line
with expectations. Our EPS estimates increase by 3% in both FY16 and
FY17. We remain Overweight with an increased price target of 610p,
March 2017 (was 600p to Dec-16).
 Solid headline performance. Revenue was up 13.9% (12.4% proforma)
to £706m, in line with our estimate of £707m. EBITDA was £155.3m,
1% above our estimate of £154.2m. Adjusted PBT was £102.8m, up
37% and above our estimate of £94.1m and Bloomberg consensus of
£96.2m due mainly to a lower depreciation charge. Adjusted EPS was
31.7p, which was above our estimate of 27.9p and Bloomberg consensus
of 28.3p due to lower depreciation and a lower effective tax rate.

12:08 pm
BE

 Margin expansion. As well as increasing overall admissions by 6.5%,
Cineworld achieved growth in average ticket prices and retail spend per
person. This, coupled with operating cost efficiencies, allowed the
EBITDA margin to expand from 20.4% to 22.0%.
 Outlook is positive. We believe the outlook for further growth in 2016
is very positive. We expect a further 13 new sites to be opened (6 in the
UK and 7 in CEE/Israel). We also believe that Cineworld's business
model will see it outperform the UK box office in 2016.
 Changes to earnings estimates. There are no material changes to our
adjusted EBITDA estimates, which remain £170m in FY16 and £185m
in FY17. The assumption of a lower depreciation charge means our
operating profit estimates increase by 3% from £114.1m to £117.4m in
FY16 and by 2% from £125.3m to £128.4m in FY17. Our adjusted EPS
estimates increase by 3% from 32.3p to 33.2p in FY16 and by 3% from
35.4p to 36.4p in FY17.

12:08 pm
BE

Cineworld's FY15 results were slightly ahead of consensus driven by the UK Other line
which includes film advertising. But we believe it could have been so much better.
Cineworld lost UK box office market share in FY15 and we estimate that it could be
missing out on as much as £2.2m of additional EBITDA per blockbuster in the UK.
Assuming a blockbuster/quarter that puts Cineworld’s missed UK opportunity at £8.8m.
For Bond, Hunger Games and Star Wars, the scale of the missed opportunity could have
been as much as £6.6m. The FY16 film slate is weaker and we do not expect consensus
to change materially. We retain our HOLD recommendation as the share price is below
our target price.
Detail
Cineworld reported FY15 EBITDA of £155.3m (+22.7%) and Adj PBT of £102.8m
(+37.15) with both reporting divisions performing equally well. To put performance into
context, Cineworld lost UK market share with box office revenue +8.0% versus market
+17.4%. Q1 has been saved by Deadpool, but the film slate is weaker this year with
the mix to more family films and less blockbusters, no material change to consensus is
expected at this stage.
The openings programme is on track: 18 new cinemas opened in FY15 and Cineworld
will continue to open 13-14 new multiplexes per annum from now on. The dividend was
+30% to 17.5p and net debt/EBITDA reduced by £37m to £282m. Cineworld can fund all
requirements from cashflow.
Cineworld has appointed Mr Dean Moore as interim CFO for 12 months pending the
promotion of Nissan Cohen to the job, who becomes deputy CFO.
Valuation
Yesterday's closing share price of 480p values the stock on a P/E of 16.1x for FY16E and
15.1x for FY17E, and EV/EBITDA of 8.9x falling to 8.2x, and FCF yield of 9.2% rising to
9.9%. Our 500p share price target is based on a PE of 16.8x, an EV/EBITDA of 9.2x and
8.8% FCF for FY16E. The default Quest® valuation is 302p. The stock has performed
relatively well compared to IMAX and Cineplex. Our CG preferred stock remains IMAX
(IMAX : NYSE : US$32 | BUY, TP: US$37).
